title.narrative: Arab Council for the Social Sciences 2017-2021
Arab Council for the Social Sciences 2017-2021

description.narrative:
Arab Council for the Social Sciences (ACSS) söker 25 miljoner kronor för att finansiera sin strategiska plan under perioden 2017-2021. ACSS är en oberoende regional NGO, ett forskningsråd och nätverk inom samhällsvetenskap och humaniora med målsättning att stödja och främja forskning, forskningskapacitet, och spridning av forskningsresultat om och för MENA regionen av arabiska forskare.
Det övergripande målet i den strategiska planen som gäller 2016-2020 är att: ge stöd till forskare och akademiska institutioner med avsikt att bidraga till kunskapsproduktion, spridning, validering och användning av samhällsvetenskaplig forskning; att berika offentlig debatt angående de utmaningar som arabiska samhällen står inför; samt att förstärka rollen av samhällsvetenskap inom det arabiska allmänna samhällsutrymmet (public life) och att arbeta för att samhällsventenskaperna informerar offentlig policy i regionen.
För att nå detta mål organiserar ACSS ett antal kärnaktiviteter: öppna utlysningar (open call) av stipendier för forskare; tematiska och komparativa forskningsgrupper; mentorprogram för unga forskare; kapacitetstärkande utbildningar (metod/etik/genus/policy/forskningsansökningsförfarande); akademiska konferenser och seminarier; tematiska on-line kurser för MA och PhD studenter som supplement till tillgängligt utbud i regionen; samt policydialog event mellan forskare och beslutsfattare. Sidas bedömning är att de planerade aktiviteterna för att genomföra den strategiska planen och öka kunskapsprodutionen är väl motiverade och genomförbara under rådande (regionala) omständigheter.
Då den femåriga ACSS strategin löper ut 2020 medan Sidas avtal med finansiering för ACSSs strategi löper till och med 2021, kommer Sida under 2019 sätta särskilt fokus på diskussioner med parten ang. organisationens framtida strategi. Utbetalning för 2021 kommer att villkoras emot att Sida har emottagit en ny strategi som är relevant för Sveriges 'Strategi för forskningssamarbete och forskning inom utvecklingssamarbetet 2015-2021', vilket noteras i avtalet.
ACSS är en ung organisation som endast verkat drygt fyra år. Sida har stött ACSS sedan 2009, innan dess officiella registrering vilket skedde 2011. Formellt började aktiviteterna sent under året 2012. Under denna korta period har organisationen har vuxit snabbt. 2010 var den årliga budgeten 1,5 miljoner kronor och Sida var den enda givaren. 2015 hade ACSS årliga budget vuxit till 22,9 miljoner SEK, och år 2016 stod årsbudgeten på 26,5 miljoner SEK - nu med sex givare (Ford Foundation; Carnegie Corporation; IDRC; Mellon Foundation; UNESCO och Sida). Nuvarande Sida avtal (2013-2016) består av 5 MSEK per år i riktat stöd. Det nya avtalet (2017-2021) avser att ligga på samma summa per år men nu med kärnstöd. En viktig utveckling är att även Ford Foundation går in med kärnstöd 2017-2021, vilket ger ACSS stabilitet och flexibilitet att arbetare vidare med sin fem-årsstrategi. Sidas bedömning är att organisationen trots sin korta existens har en väl fungerande styrning och kontroll, ett starkt ägarskap för sitt program, och har en god finansiering för strategiperiodens intentioner. En möjlig intern risk är att ACSS kan växa för fort, men med kärnstöd från två givare har organisationen valt att under ett års tid rikta arbetet inåt för att stärka intern kapacitet och utvärdera kortsiktiga mål. Detta inkluderar även att begränsa kortsiktiga projektuppdrag till fördel för långsiktiga avtal som direkt relaterar till strategin.
ACSS huvudkontor, dess sekretariat, med ansvar för implementering för programmen, är lokaliserad i Libanons huvudstad Beirut. Vid sekretariatet arbetar sju personer från olika delar av MENA ). ACSS styrs av generalförsamlingen (General Assembly) som möts vartannat år vid en konferens och består av ACSSs institutionella och individuella medlemmar. Mellan generalförsamlingens möten styrs organisationen av styrelsen (Board of Trustees) bestående av tolv valda medlemmar. Styrelsen träffas två gånger per år. Det är Sidas bedömning att organisationen fungerar väl, dock behövs ytterligare förtydligande av ansvarsfördelning mellan sektretariat och styrelsen (ett pågående arbete som avslutas 2017 med den då nyvalda styrelsen).
Sida bedömer att ACSSs arbete med att stödja relevant forskning inom samhällsvetenskap och humaniora samt utveckling av forskningskapacitet är viktig och relevant. Detta inom MENA regionens kontext med begränsad samhällsvetenskaplig forskning och otillräcklig kapacitet, och särskilt med tanke på forskares begränsade möjlighet att verka då akademisk frihet, yttrandefrihet och kritiskt tänkande inte välkomnas i alla kontexter och regionen är drabbad av politiska spänningar, konflikter och krig.

The Arab Council for the Social Sciences (ACSS) has applied for 25 million SEK to finance it's Strategic Plan (2016-2020). The ACSS is an independent regional NGO, a research council and a network in social sciences and the humanities with the goal to support and enhance research, research capacity, and the dissemination of research results in and on the MENA region by Arab researchers. The objective stated in the Strategic Plan is: 'by supporting researchers and academic/research institutions, the ACSS aims to contribute to the creation, dissemination, validation, and utilisation of social science research and to enrich public debate about the challenges facing Arab societies. The ACSS also aims to enhance the role of social science in Arab public life and inform public policy in the region'.The activities includes: open calls for research grants; thematic and comparative research groups; mentorship program for research and advocacy; capacity building workshops; academic conferences and seminars; thematic on-line courses for MA and PhD students supplementing offerings by regional universities; and policy dialogue events between researchers and decision-makers. As the five-year ACSS strategy shall expire 2020 whilst Sida's agreement is valid until year 2021, Sida shall in 2019 put particular focus on partner discssions regarding the organisation's new strategy beyond 2020. A prerequisite for a disbursement in 2019 is Sida’s approval of the new Strategy for the Arab Council for the Social Sciences starting year 2021 and that this Strategy is still relevant to Sweden’s Strategy for Research Cooperation 2015-2021', which is defined in the agreement. The ACSS is a new organisation that has been fully operational for only a little more than four years. Sida has supported the ACSS since 2009, before the organisation was registered, which took place in 2011. Formally the activities started in late 2012. During this short period the organisation has grown quickly. 2015 the ACSS budget had grown to 22,9 million SEK, and 2016 the annual budget had increased to 26,5 million SEK - now with six funders (Ford Foundation; Carnegie Corporation; IDRC; Mellon Foundation; UNESCO; and Sida). The current Sida agreement (2013-2016) includes 5mSEK per year in program support. The new agreement (2017-2021) is intended to have the same annual budget but now with core support. An important development is that Ford Foundation is also going to support the ACSS with core support for the same five year period, which gives the ACSS stability and flexibility to work with its five year Strategic Plan. Sida's assessment is that despite the ACSS being a young organisation, it has a well functioning control and regulation frameworks, the ownership for the program is strong, and it has solid funding for the five year period covered by the Strategic Plan. The ACSS office, it's Secretariat, is responsible for implementing activities and is located in Beirut, Lebanon. Seven employees from various parts of the MENA region work in this office). The ACSS is governed by a General Assembly which meets every other year at a conference bringing together institutional and individual members. Between general assembly meetings the organisation is governed by a Board of Trustees consisting of 12 selected members. The board meets twice a year. It is Sida's assessment that the organisation functions well, however there is a need for further clarification in relation to roles and responsibilities between the Secretariat and the Board, a matter to which action has been taken and shall be finalised in 2017 with the then newly elected Board.

The intended outcome is to identify the needs of social scientists and social science communities, increase the knowledge production of high quality social sciences and humanities research addressing the priority development challenges of the Arab region and enhance engagement with such research.

title.narrative: Agreement on core support to the Arab Council for the Social Sciences, 2017-21
Beslut om insats, Arab Council for the Social Sciences (ACSS) 2017-2021

description.narrative: The covid-19 pandemic during 2020 has affected the ACSS. Some activities have been postponed, while others have transformed into digital events. Most notably, the biennial Research Forum, planned for April 2020, was cancelled. In addition, the organisation has put a lot of energy into other developments in Lebanon. The uprisings in October 2019 led, among other things, to a banking crises, that complicated ACSS funds management. This has resulted in an ongoing exploration of establishing ACSS branches in other locations. The ambition is now to establish a branch in Jordan and a company limited by guarantee in Abu Dhabi, UAE. Also, the severe explosion in Beirut in August 2020 caused significant damage to the ACSS office. The ACSS has managed to adapt to the situation. It has transferred to digital interaction for internal work as well as for many external events. Although there have been postponement or cancellation of some major activities, many training workshops, seminars, and working groups activities have been maintained. The digital transformation has also opened up for more inclusive interaction. The pandemic has affected the important ACSS grants and fellowships program. The outbreak of the pandemic negatively affected the ability of grantees to conduct fieldwork and complete their projects on time. However, the lockdown imposed by the pandemic was used efficiently and has led to a series of strategy meetings for the program between March and April 2020. One result of these interactions is a comprehensive database for all grants and awarded grantees since the establishment of the ACSS, which may be used to generate qualitative and quantitative analysis about the work of the grantees and assist in determining research trends and identifying emerging themes in the region. An example of activity within the research grant program concerned the three cycles of calls on the theme of “Environmentalism, Impoverishment and Social Justice Movements: Interdisciplinary Perspectives”. The ACSS together with the ODUM Institute for Research in Social Science (University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, US) organized a workshop titled “Environmentalism in the Arab Region: Concepts and Methods”. The call targeted applicants to the Researech Grant Program whose projects were among the top ranked but were not selected to receive a grant. The workshop combined methodological and research design with substantive environmental issues. Participants could directly apply what they were learning during the workshop on their work in progress and receive comments from the instructors. In early 2020, the fellowship program New Paradigms Factory (NPF) launched its fourth cycle on the theme “Gendered Resistance.” Four prominent gender scholars from the region representing different disciplinary and thematical dimensions, were appointed as mentors to work closely with fellows on developing their writing skills and improving their articles. A promising new activity is the program entitled “A new generation of social scientists in the Arab region (2030) (NewGen)”. This fellowship provides a two-years multi component journey – including training, research and networking opportunities - for students at the BA, MA and Ph.D. levels at selected Arab universities. The aim of the program is to help create a “pipeline” of students starting with the BA and continuing on to the Ph.D. who would form a new cohort of social scientists committed to critical scholarship. It also seeks to engage Arab academic institutions and campuses to form a network of universities that support students nationally and regionally. NewGen is now in its 1st cycle and will launch the 2nd cycle in February 2021. The second series of the ACSS Annual Lecture event celebrates the Moroccan sociologist and activist, Fatema Mernissi. The Annual Lecture are given in honor of prominent social scientists from the Arab region and encourages research along the paradigms and perspectives that they developed. The second Fatema Mernissi lecture titled "Religious Knowledge in the Arab World from a Feminist Perspective: From Critique to Reconstruction" was presented as a virtual event by Dr. Omaima Abou-Bakr, professor of English and Comparative Literature at Cairo University on December 17, 2020. The five different Working Groups (groups of researchers who conduct research, training and gatherings on various themes) have been able to advance relevant research and other activities, despite the pandemic. The Critiques of Power Working Group concluded its activities in late 2020 after more than four years, although the network established will continue to be engaged in ACSS activities of various forms. The Ethnography as Knowledge Working Group was launched in 2019, and lists a number of activities in 2020. Several working groups note that there is a shortage of scientists in the region in specific areas. The Critical Security Studies Working Group, for instance, an interdisciplinary network of scholars pursuing research that challenges the dominant understanding of the Arab region as a threat to global security, is developing into the “Beirut School of Critical Security Studies”, which does include research collaboration with elements of training and mentorships. There are also ongoing collaboration with CLACSO in Latin America within this working group. The ACSS is leading the Arab Region’s contribution to the World Humanities Report (WHR), a Mellon funded initiative with support from UNESCO. The WHR is an outcome of the 2017 World Humanities Conference in Liège. It marked the launch of a cross-regional collaboration to identify and promote the conditions under which the humanities might flourish in the next decade. The aim of the current WHR report is to encourage humanistic methods and understandings in knowledge production and in socio-economic, political innovation more generally. The Arab Social Science Monitor (ASSM) is an observatory of the landscape of the social sciences and higher education in the Arab region.The Third Arab Social Science Monitor Report (ASSR3) is titled “The academic universes of social scientists in the Arab world: Career trajectories and networks in universities”. The ASSM also carries out the periodic survey of Arab social scientists with the aim of better understanding their characteristics and career trajectories. This data gathering has continued during 2020. One ASSM result is the commissioned paper “Academic Challenges in the Time of Covid-19: Arab Social Scientists and Humanists in Focus”, authored by Dr. Caroline Krafft, consultant. The paper reports substantial decreases in teaching, learning, and research, which will affect the careers of a generation of scholars and also the state of knowledge in and about the Arab region. Overall, the study concludes that "COVID-19 presents steep challenges to scholars in the region, particularly for those in countries already facing a surplus of challenges, and especially for those already facing disadvantages, such as female scholars juggling care for young children. Although the course of the pandemic and the region’s response remain uncertain and evolving, there is the potential to motivate and create changes to address long-standing challenges and disparities, or for the pandemic and regional response to further exacerbate inequality and pre-existing problems." In 2016, the ACSS launched a pilot project to promote regional collaboration on relevant research ethics guidelines, practices and structures. All along, the ACSS has continued to conduct trainings and workshops on research ethics for ACSS grantees and NGOs in various countries in the Arab region (Palestine, Jordan, Algeria and Lebanon). These activities will form the basis of the next phase of this project which will culminate in the building up and launching of “The Arab Platform for Ethical Research in the Social Sciences,” an online, interactive training website which will enhance and promote the work of ACSS under this initiative. In 2020 ACSS collaborated with AUB and Birzeit University in an IDRC-funded grant on ethics that suggests a number of activities: a mapping of existing institutional practices and processes with a focus on universities (AUB), developing, hosting, and operating a learning portal (Birzeit) and supporting new research and training on research ethics (ACSS). The ACSS notes a great interest for the ethics issues, especially among younger social scientists in the region. The ACSS has intensified collaborations with CLACSO in 2020. One idea is to form a cross regional working group on “Security Policies and Insecurity Production in Latin America and the Middle East”, a topic of great relevance to the Arab and Latin American regions. In addition to this, discussions are also underway with CLACSO for the formation of a working group on higher education that would engage the ACSS, CLACSO and CODESRIA . The working group would focus on the right to education from a Global South perspective and would adopt a comparative research perspective. In addition, ACSS is collaborating with CLACSO in its Latin American Forum on Research Evaluation (FOLEC-Foro Latinoamericano sobre Evaluación Científica). This forum focuses on different dimensions around research assessment and aims to generate proposals from Latin America and the Caribbean, in dialogue with international trends and good practices, mainly in the SSH, where diversity of voices and contributions are so important for open science and SDG research agendas. The ACSS also collaborates with CODESRIA in a project on humanities research in the Sahel region, to be funded by Sida. The Sahel project has the potential to be a significant cross regional initiative that could present a model for similar 57 collaborations between South-South organizations as well as researchers from across the African continent. It is also promising in the sense that it would challenge colonial and security discourses about the Sahel region, that overlook the cultural richness of the region and the resilience and adaptation capacities of its inhabitants.
